TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable sealed WindowsBuiltInRole extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies common roles to be used with .

remarks.format:
## Remarks These roles represent the local Windows groups common to most installations of Windows NT, Windows 2000 and Windows XP.
> [!NOTE] > In Windows Vista, User Account Control (UAC) determines the privileges of a user. If you are a member of the Built-in Administrators group, you are assigned two run-time access tokens: a standard user access token and an administrator access token. By default, you are in the standard user role. When you attempt to perform a task that requires administrative privileges, you can dynamically elevate your role by using the Consent dialog box. The code that executes the <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsPrincipal.IsInRole%2A> method does not display the Consent dialog box. The code returns false if you are in the standard user role, even if you are in the Built-in Administrators group. You can elevate your privileges before you execute the code by right-clicking the application icon and indicating that you want to run as an administrator.
## Examples The following example shows the use of the <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole> enumeration.
[!code-cpp[System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_CLR_System/system.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_CLR_System/system.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_CLR_System/system.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole AccountOperator = int32(548)

Docs.summary: Account operators manage the user accounts on a computer or domain.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Administrator = int32(544)

Docs.summary: Administrators have complete and unrestricted access to the computer or domain.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole BackupOperator = int32(551)

Docs.summary: Backup operators can override security restrictions for the sole purpose of backing up or restoring files.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Guest = int32(546)

Docs.summary: Guests are more restricted than users.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole PowerUser = int32(547)

Docs.summary: Power users possess most administrative permissions with some restrictions. Thus, power users can run legacy applications, in addition to certified applications.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole PrintOperator = int32(550)

Docs.summary: Print operators can take control of a printer.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole Replicator = int32(552)

Docs.summary: Replicators support file replication in a domain.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole SystemOperator = int32(549)

Docs.summary: System operators manage a particular computer.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole User = int32(545)

Docs.summary: Users are prevented from making accidental or intentional system-wide changes. Thus, users can run certified applications, but not most legacy applications.
